body:
I'm unable to repro this. Would you mind trying this again with `alacritty --print-events -e vim` and take note of what happens between the time it hangs and actually exits?

> 144 Hz monitor

I've been wanting to try Alacritty on one of those; sounds fun!
I'll also add, this mostly occurs when, after writing ``:q``, I press and release enter very fast. If you hold the final enter for more milliseconds the prompt sometimes exits cleanly.
That's because of a `keyup` event emitted after vim exit, and so it's still dependent on such keystroke.

The issue comes from event loop which needs to be notified when child process exits. Currently the `sigchld` function in `tty.rs` handles this event and just sets `SHOULD_EXIT` flag, while the event loop is waiting for new events from window system. One __hack__ can be manually faking an event to the terminal window using unsafe C code. The better solution is to create a new stream to `poll` and trigger it on `sigchld`. I don't have enough knowledge about the internal design and control flow, but am interested in fixing this.

Reproduction can be done by running a command that takes a while to finish automatically (such as `sync`) through `-e` as argument, under gdb to watch the traceback. Then killing it using `SIGSTOP` and looking `where` it is hanging (goes down to `poll`). Sending signal can be automatically done this way to avoid triggering unwanted key events (assuming one instance is running):
```bash
$ sleep 3 && pgrep alacritty | xargs kill -SIGSTOP
```
FWIW `nvim` doesn't seem to have this problem, so if you're looking for a quick workaround, using neovim should work.

issue.title: Static display notification on SIGCHLD
issue.body:
Ensures that the window processor wakes up upon SIGCHLD.
Otherwise, after `exit` or `logout`, the user had to trigger
a window event before alacritty closed.

Fixes #1313.
Fixes #1276.
Fixes #915.

Relevant parts: `main.rs` :  110 - 114, `tty.rs` : 43 - 64

issue.title: Fix lingering window after child process exit on unix
issue.body:
This is a crack at handing `SIGCHLD` (and conceivably others) safely and correctly, taking a different approach to #1367 by using the well-known "self-pipe trick". This should allay concerns about non- _async-signal-safe_ functions in signal handlers.

The signal handler writes received `SIG*` numbers into a pipe, which wakes up the existing I/O event loop. The loop then delegates handling back to the `Pty`, which reads the pipe, and reacts appropriately.

I'm not 100% certain on the finer points of this design, though, so I'd appreciate some feedback.

- Fixes #915
- Fixes #1276
- Fixes #1313

issue.body:

Windows Insider Preview, and Alacritty is running `wsl.exe -d arch -u me`, where arch is a WSL 2 machine.

When I run `wsl.exe --shutdown` (Immediately terminates all running distributions and the WSL 2 lightweight utility virtual machine.), the program that Alacritty was running is killed off, but the Alacritty window remains around until I press a key, move the mouse or something similar.
